news us-news pet-chimp-owner-screams-he-"Travis the Chimp: Sandra Heralds  call in ByEmma GrittOnline journalist:,  Jan | commentsItaposs hard to know what is more chilling about Sandra Heroldaposs  call - hearing her helpless sobbing as she reveals her pet chimp is eating her friendaposs face, or the apeaposs frenzied screams in the background.For an excruciating  minutes, Sandra is heard pleading for police to rush to her home to shoot dead Travis, the animal she had raised as her own son for the previous  years, reports the Daily Star. Tell me, what is the monkey doing , the operator asks as Travisaposs harrowing, almost gleeful, wails and screeches echo down the line. He ripped her apart! Hurry up! Hurry up! Please!” Herold breathlessly replies. “He—he ripped her face off! Heaposs eating her face! “Gun! They got to shoot him! Please! Please! Hurry! Hurry! Please! I can’t. I can’t … He’s eating her! He’s eating her! Please! God! Please! Where are they  Where are they ” Officers did come and Travis was killed. Astonishingly, his victim, Charla Nash, survived, but you could argue that in many ways, her le too came to an abrupt end that day.  Charla, a friend of Travisapos aposmomapos Sandra, had been asked to pop over to help put the pampered ape in his enclosure - but, uncharacteristically, he snapped, attacking her and gnawing off her face and hands. In a show of terrying primal strength, Travis ripped off her eyelids and tore off her nose. He scalped her, gouged out and ate her eyes, chewed off one of her hands entirely and almost tore one of her arms off. Her jaw was entirely dislocated from her skull and she was left with brain damage. It is still not known why Travis - a local celebrity who would eat lobster in restaurants, had a pet cat, and loved driving around on a lawnmower - flipped out the way that he did that day.  Sandra later admitted giving him a dose of strong anti-anxiety medicine Xanax in his daily cup of tea earlier that day when she noticed that he was aposagitatedapos. She also claimed that he behaved viciously because Charla was wearing her hair dferently. But it could also have been that at the age of , the lbapeaposs instincts had simply become too strong - or that he was simply sick of his unnatural lestlye of cooking his own microwave meals, drinking wine at dinner, and using the toilet like a human. Sandra had owned Travis since he was just three days old, paying a breeder , for the infant chimp.  His mum was shot with a tranquiliser dart so that he could be stolen away - and from that moment on, he was no longer a chimpanzee, but Sandraaposs apossonapos. To outsiders they had an unbreakable bond, and even shared a bed after Sandraaposs husband died. After the attack on February , , the then -year-old told reporters: He couldnapost be more my son thanI gave birth to him. But everything has a breaking point, and for Sandra, that came when she saw her beloved aposlittle boyapos mauling her best friend.  Due to Charlaaposs horric injuries, Sandra was the only person able to explain exactly what had prompted the attack. She claimed Travis approached Charla aggressively before getting onto his hind legs and launching the savage attack, throwing her against the side of her car before gorging on her face and hands. Desperate, Sandra stabbed him in the back with a carving kne and battered him over the head with a shovel in a bid to make him stop, which it did for a moment. She recalled how he turned around and looked at her, before she ran for her le and locked herself in her car.  Sandra said: “I grabbed the shovel and hit him with the shovel to stop it. It wasnapost working, so I went and I had to get a kne — and I stabbed him. I had to. He looked at me like, ‘Mom, what did you do ’” When police arrived, Travis was in a frenzy of bloodlust. He opened one of their patrol caraposs doors and lunged at an officer. Despite being shot four times at point blank range Travis didnapost die. He ran back in to the house, and collapsed dead on his special bed, leaving a trail of blood behind him.  The gunshots are heard in the background of Sandraaposs breathless  call. When paramedics arrived on the scene they were unable to decipher the victimaposs gender due to the severity of the wounds. Like something from a horror film, strips of flesh and scalp had been flung around the yard of Sandraaposs Stamford, Connecticut, home. They assumed that Charla, who was a mass of bloodied flesh with no recognisable facial features slumped in a pool of her own blood, was dead - until she moved. They sprung into action, and managed to save her le.  The brutal attack had caused her to lose half of her blood and she would later undergo a face transplant. Sadly, a pioneering hand transplant was rejected by her body. After the incident, NBC reporter Jeff Rossen asked Sandra: “After what youaposve been through with this — your friend is in the hospital fighting for her le — do you still think chimps should be pets  She replied: “Would I have done it again  Yes! Theyaposre the closest thing to humans — to us. “We can give them a blood transfusion, and they can give us one. How many people go crazy and kill other people  This is one incident that I donapost know what happened. “It was a horrible thing. But Iaposm not a horrible person. And he wasnapost a horrible chimp. It was a freak thing.”  Fteen months later Sandy died from an aneurysm. She was buried with two urns beside her. One was her daughteraposs, the other belonged to Travis. The only survivor of that hideous day is Charla Nash, who now lives in darkness, wearing someone aposs face and entirely dependent on the staff at the care home where she will spend the rest of her days. Ahead of the face transplant she spoke to Oprah Winfrey, and rued the loss of the le she loved. She said: Iaposve never been a quitter. Unfortunately, thereaposs not a whole lot I can do. “I’ve lost so much independence. I could change my own truck tyre, and now I can’t even feed myself. Itaposs very hard to live. Not even live - half-live. “Sometimes you want to cry, you want out, you want some kind of home. I donapost know what my future is, thataposs the scary part. title: currys driver sends creepy texts
story: Currys driver sends creepy texts to customer - but its her boyfriends phoneRyan Sager couldnt believe it when a creepy Currys driver sent him flirty text messages which were actually meant for his fiance - so he decided to have a little fun with itKacey couldnt believe it when the creepy Currys driver couldnt stop staring Image: Kennedy News and MediaByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA creepy Currys driver has been left red-faced, after sending a number of flirty messages to a customer - only to discover he was actually messaging her boyfriend. Kacey Wheeler recently had a washing machine delivered from the electrical retailer and claims the delivery man couldnapost stop staring at her when doing the drop off in Bradford last week. The -year-old even called her fiance Ryan Sager shortly afterwards to joke the man, known only as Jordan, was in love with her, but they were both gobsmacked when he texted her  minutes later. What Jordan didnapost know, however, was that the mobile number on the order sheet actually belonged to Ryan - as the washing machine had been a gt from his parents. As soon as I opened the door I saw one of the guys just didnapost take his eyes off me. I didnapost take it in a weird way at first and I thought it was funny. He was just staring at me, Kacey said. The other guy just came in, dropped the washer and then left, but the other guy didnapost want to leave. He was lingering around telling me where to put it and opening draws. It was really creepy but at the time I just thought it was strange. I was winding Ryan up telling him the driver was in love with me, then I thought he was joking when he said heaposd got texts from him. I canapost believe he just took the number off the sheet and he knows where we live. Evenheaposd have come into my house and asked for my number it wouldnapost have been as weird.Not happy at the driveraposs advances, Ryan decided to embarrass Jordan by engaging in a flirty six-hour text exchange, which he later shared to Facebook.Posing as his six-months-pregnant fiancee, Ryan began chatting with Jordan who bragged about being a former prison bad boy and cheekily suggested they should meet up to get this washer sorted. In the six-hour chat Ryan, , even asked Jordan, who claimed to be chilling at Currys self-employed, to be his sugar daddy after he bragged about earning £, per year. Electrician Ryan believes he aposintimidatedapos the delivery worker with his late-night request of a threesome and description of naughty bedroom kinks - including a request he dress up as a Marvel superhero. When the Currys driver tried to continue the chat the next day, Ryan abruptly cut him off saying, f*** off now, Iaposm bored, before revealing Jordan had actually been talking to Kaceyaposs fiance for hours. Despite the light-hearted prank to waste Jordanaposs time, Ryan has been angered by the delivery manaposs cheek and Kacey now says sheaposs afraid to accept deliveries without her fiance in the house. Ryan said: Thereaposs my shoes in the house, Kaceyaposs six months pregnant and sheaposs got an engagement ring on. Itaposs just utter disrespect. When I got the phone call and the text came through I was annoyed, but then I thought Iaposd make a laugh out of it. I thought aposIaposm going to [pull] your legapos. My favourite bit was asking him to dress up in a Marvel costume and him replying that heaposs a prison boy. He was trying to big himself up. Itaposs embarrassing. He deserves to have the mick taken out of him. From the texts you can tell heaposs a very strange guy. I thought Iaposd scared him off on the night, talking about a threesome, but then when he messaged back the next day and I wasnapost having a good day at work so I just told him to f*** off. Iaposm happy heaposs wasted all that time. Every time I put something provocative, heaposd have been sitting there on his couch sweating, thinking aposwhat do I do with his girlapos. He thought heaposd pulled. If it was me Iaposd have felt tiny. I hope he feels like an idiot. If he came back to the house heaposd get it, but itaposs a shame for Kacey. You shouldnapost be made uncomfortable by delivery drivers like that. Currys said they were treating the matter aposvery seriouslyapos and confirmed they are currently investigating it.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. news weird-news dna-testing-decide-whether-worlds-"Doug the Spud: New Zealand potato weighs nearly kgByKieren WilliamsNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A potato that could be the world’s biggest spud is being forced to undergo DNA testing to prove it’s actually a potato.Colin and Donna Craig-Brown discovered the monstrous .kg potato in their vegetable garden in August. They nicknamed their finding, which weighs twice as much as the average newborn, ‘Doug’. However, now, the New Zealand found spud will have to undergo DNA analysis to prove it’s a spud before it can claim its spot in the record books. This has left the couple dejected and feeling betrayed. Colin confirmed that they were requiring that a sample of Doug be sent to Scotland despite the experts, agronomists and field scientists the couple have had to very the find.  He said: “Do they think I genetically modied it  It’s been a rollercoaster of emotion. “While it’s extremely deflating, I want to prove them wrong. We will do everything they ask of us.” A bit of Doug will end up at Researchers at Science and Advice for Scottish Agriculturewho provide agricultural advice to the Scottish government.  They will genotype Doug to confirm he is a potato and possibly what iety he is too. The Guinness World Records confirmed they were in touch with the biology department but Sasa has not yet received the bit of Doug. The couple described the potato as their “happy little mistake of nature” they came across when the hoe struck something large. Speaking to Stuff, Colin said: “It’s a hideous looking creature. “It’s the sort of thing that only a mother could love.” The couple think the potato is self-sown and could have been growing for a couple of years or more.  Whilst they await confirmation to seeDoug will take his place in the annals of history, they have built a small cart to tow the potato around town and show it off. However, Colin is concerned about how long the potato will last for as it has already started to lose weight as it dries out and turns mouldy. To ensure some preservation he has stored it in a freezer. The current heaviest potato was found in Britain in  and weight only just under kg, far less than Doug. title: harry potter plot hole fans
story: Harry Potter plot hole has fans convinced Dumbledore is the real villainHarry Potter fan Brenna took to TikTok to share her controversial theory that Dumbledore is really a villain thanks to this scene in the seventh film of the franchise, Deathly Hallows Image: Courtesy Warner Bros.ByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Jan | commentsItaposs been  years since the first Harry Potter film was released and fans are still finding plot holes. Now one person believes theyaposve spotted a pretty major one in Deathly Hallows, the seventh film of the fantasy franchise.Potter fan Brenna took to TikTok @bihlito share the theory, in which she says Dumbledore is the real villain. In a video that has been viewed more than . million times, she laid out her argument.In Deathly Hallows, we see Bill Weasley and Fleuraposs cottage being used as a safe house for Harry Potteraposs allies in the wizarding war. This is because Bill is a secret keeper, which means he has been selected to hide a secret by means of the Fidelius Charm. The person who told the secret can then no longer pass on the information that has been given to the secret keeper, and only they , can reveal it.  For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. They are then able to tell as many people as they like, but only on a voluntary basis - it must not be tortured or blackmailed out of them. And as a Weasley, the Order of the Phoenix can trust Bill to keep Harry Potter’s whereabouts hidden. However, Brenna questioned why Harryaposs parents, Lily and James, werenapost secret keepers of Harryaposs whereabouts instead. When Voldemort tried to kill Harry, the couple were forced to go into hiding, and Peter Pettigrew was their secret keeper, who ended up telling Voldemort where they were. Therefore, fans believe this makes Albus Dumbledore - the Hogwarts headmaster - the true villain as he seemingly orchestrated the events that would see Lily and James killed so that he could use Harry to defeat Voldemort himself. Since being posted, the video has racked up more than , likes and , comments from fans who were quick to share their surprise at the plot hole. Because Dumbledore is the villain she didnapost mean to write, said one person. Another wrote: Dumbledore was such a gaslighter. All this horrible stuff happens to Harry and D tells him it’s because aposI cared for you too much!apos A third commented: JK Rowling would be distressed to be asked a question like that. Someone  put: This is because Dumbledore needed either Sirius or Remus to go to prison so neither of them could take care of Harry and he could send him to his aunt. But others werenapost convinced by her theory as one person said: Dumbledore isnapost the villain. Heaposs extremely complex but heaposs all for the greater good. The end goal outweighs the casualties, in his opinion. Iaposm confused why people are saying Dumbledore is a civilian  asked another. Adding: He literally offers to be the Potters secret keeper and they turned him down.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: i drive secondhand hearse its
story: I drive a secondhand hearse - its great for naps and no its not hauntedWhile most -year-olds are driving around in Fiat s or Corsas, Hailey Rose drives a  secondhand hearse, which she says is perfect for napping and hanging out with friendsIts not your typical mode of transport Image: x.hailey.rose.x TikTokByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Jan | comments When you think of most -year-olds who drive, you might think of them driving a Fiat , a Corsa or even an Audi,they happen to have a lot of money. But, the chances are, a hearse is the last vehicle youaposd expect someone of that age to be driving - unless they work in a funeral home, obviously. Hailey Rose @x.hailey.rose.xis certainly not your average -year-old, as not only does she drive around in a secondhand hearse, she also works in the film and theatre industry and does welding on the side - all of which have gained her an impressive following on TikTok.She regularly takes to TikTok to share what le is actually like driving around in a secondhand hearse, from what itaposs like to drive, to how many dead bodies it has carried. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Hailey, from Atlanta in the US, became the owner of the  hearse after her previous vehicle was hit by a truck, leaving her injured and out of work for two months. So, when investing in a new car, she thought one that everyone would slow down for would be perfect. If they were going to hit me they were going to feel bad about it, she explained in one clip. Another obvious perk of driving a hearse is the space in the back, where Hailey has strategically placed a bed, which she uses to nap on during really long days when sheaposs working in theatre - so she can catch up on rest during her lunch breaks. She added: Itaposs also just really cosy to hang out with friends back here. I am definitely excited to take it on a road trip one day. Hailey, who says sheaposs experienced paranormal activity in the past, promises that her hearse is not haunted, despite having carried approximately  dead bodies to funerals during its two decades of service.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: mum vows burn house down
story: Mum vows to burn the house down after seeing huge spider drop on sleeping babyEmily Stewarts baby monitor captured the heart-stopping moment a giant spider dangled from the ceiling and dropped into her babys cot - leaving the mum terriedThe spider dropped down from the ceiling onto the babys head Image: @emstewie TikTokByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Jan | commentsNot many of us are fans of spiders at the best of times, but whatone crawled into your bed while you were asleep and blissfully unaware  Thataposs what happened to one little girl named Kyla, whose mum only realised what had been visiting her daughter in the middle of the night after reviewing footage from her baby monitor. Emily Stewart, from Bradley, Illinois, USA, recorded the baby monitor footage of the giant eight-legged creature and posted it to TikTok - much to the horror of the . million people who have viewed it so far. In the clip, which was posted to Emilyaposs account @emstewie, the huge spider can be seen crawling across the lens of the camera before dangling down into Kylaaposs cot while she slept soundly. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Emily captioned the video: Trigger warning! I think my le would have been betterI didn’t see this. Now I have to burn the house down. The spider appeared to land near the babyaposs head, but the angle of the camera meant the monster disappeared from view - leaving viewers on TikTok concerned. But the mum insisted her daughter was okay, and said the spider came back up to the ceiling shortly after the footage stopped - and has since been squished. She added in a comment: Baby is okay! She was not bitten. The spider came back up a minute later and I killed it in the morning after I saw the video!  The viral video has more than .k comments, and people couldnapost help but joke about the terrying event - with many telling Emily to follow through with her promise to burn her house down. One person wrote: Save the baby, burn the house. As another added: Iaposm so sorry for your loss ... Iaposm assuming you never went to get your child again  While a third commented: The way it went down to the baby. Youaposve got to throw the room and the baby away now. Other commenters shared their own spider-related horror stories, as one mum even claimed she once found a dead spider in her sonaposs nappy. She wrote: I changed my sons nappy one day and there was literally a dead spider in his s**t. And another commenter posted: One time I felt a spider while in bed. I turned my flashlight on and found it on my toddleraposs face. Smacked him without really thinking about it. Oops! Have you got a story to share  We want to hear all about it. news world-news girl--miraculously-survives--"Russian town of Uglegorsk where young girl survived alone in blizzardByWill StewartRussia CorrespondentRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A schoolgirl miraculously survived a ferociously cold night in a snow blizzard by hugging a stray dog for warmth.Vika Z. was found with frostbite clinging on to the “fluffy” abandoned pet following a frantic search by police, officials and volunteers.She was found half a mile from home after getting lost on her way back from school in Uglegorsk on Russia’s largest island, Sakhalin.The island is known for its bitterly cold winters, where temperatures plunge to -C, police said. The blizzard led to snowfalls more than ft deep which blocked doors and windows, reaching as high as the first floor in some areas. She was eventually found  hours after she initially went missing while ing from school. It took the search team  hours to find and rescue the youngster.  To keep herself alive, she was hugging a fluffy dog for warmth, according to local media. When found, Vika was lying with the stray mongrel on a mattress which animal-loving locals had put out for homeless pooches. It was lodged under a low balcony where they could shelter from the storm.  Local media initially reported she clambered into a kennel, which was later corrected. “She was taken straight to hospital, and found to have mild frostbite,” said a local source. She had left school at pm, and was found next morning at :am. Olesya Voznyuk, an official with the Investigative Committee, said: “She was hiding under a balcony with the dog. The girl loves animals very much, she used to play with local dogs all the time.“She went to feed these dogs after school and then got caught in the snow storm and strong winds.” The space under the balcony gave some shelter but it still took more than  people over  hours to find her from when her parents raised the alarm .  Her “relieved” mother Tatyana, , was reunited with Vika at hospital. The girl was allowed home the same day . Now there are plans to honour the dog that saved Vika -they can find it after the pooch went missing. title: madeleine mccann investigators discover shocking
story: Madeleine McCann investigators discover shocking clues that incriminate suspectMadeleine McCann investigators working for TV channel Sat. have handed "shocking" evidence to detectives probing Christian Brueckner over the infamous caseChristian Brueckner is the prime suspect in the disappearance of Madeleine McCann Image: REX ShutterstockByRob HydeMartin Fricker:,  Jan  German investigators say they have uncovered “shocking” evidence which “heavily incriminates” Madeleine McCann suspect Christian Brueckner. A team working for TV channel Sat. have handed the evidence to detectives probing Brueckner over the infamous case.British youngster Madeleine was just three-years-old when she vanished from her parents’ holiday apartment in Portugal in . German prosecutors claim to have evidence she is dead and named convicted paedophile Brueckner as their only suspect. Despite going public with the information in June , they have still not charged him with any offence. But now Sat. investigators claim to have found fresh evidence linking Brueckner, who denies any involvement, to the crime. They will reveal more information about their investigation in a prime-time documentary, which is yet to have an air date. Announcing the show, Sat. said journalist Jutta Rabe and a team of reporters gathered new information about Brueckner. They claim it includes proof he was near Praia da Luz when Madeleine vanished while her parents dined in a tapas restaurant. The channel said they collected “many new clues and indications” that corroborate the suspicions of German prosecutors. Editor-in-chief Juliane Ebling said: “The sad story of Madeleine McCann is a story that has many German facets. “The case is being tried at the Regional Court of Braunschweig, as the German Christian B. is the main suspect.  “In his environment there are many German women and men who can describe inidual details surrounding the crime. “Jutta Rabe has researched shocking material in Germany, Portugal and England over the past months, which heavily incriminates Christian B.” Sat. confirmed the show will be airing on German TV but said “no exact broadcast date has been set”. When contacted by the Mirror, chief public prosecutor Hans-Christian Wolters was unavailable for comment. His office confirmed in December that they soon hope to charge Brueckner with raping a woman in Portugal. He is suspected of attacking Irish waitress Hazel Behan in the Algarve three years before Madeleine vanished.  She waived her right to anonymity two years ago to come forward and accuse Brueckner of attacking her in . The German, , is already serving a jail term for raping a pensioner in Praia da Luz in . Mr Wolters said he is % convinced” Brueckner also killed Madeleine, who was just three when she vanished. The German was living in a camper van close to Praia da Luz when Madeleine disappeared. Police first became aware of him as a suspect in  but only went public with the information in June . Since then senior investigators have interviewed a string of potential key witnesses in Germany and Portugal. The German denies being involved in Madeleine’s disappearance and has refused to speak to investigators.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Madeleine MccannCrime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: man donates kidney girlfriends mum
story: Man donates kidney to girlfriends mum - but is dumped a month after operationUziel Martínez from Mexico said in a series of TikToks that his girlfriend abandoned him less than a month after he selflessly donated her his kidneyUziel Martínez said he had helped save his partners mum - only for her to leave him weeks later Image: Uziel Martínez TikTokByThomas Haynes:,  Jan | commentsA TikToker has recounted the moment he was dumped by his girlfriend - weeks after donating his kidney to her mum. In a series of videos, Uziel Martínez, from Baja Calornia, Mexico said he had heroically stepped in to save his exaposs mother by donating the organ. Sadly for the teacher, donating an organ to his mother-in-law wasnapost enough to rescue his relationship, which ended less than a month after the operation. To add insult to injury, Uzielaposs ex has since married another man. He has since made several TikToks about the nightmare breakup as part of a recent trend.Speaking in one of the clips, he said: I donated a kidney to her mother, she left me and got married a month later.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter hereHis videos triggered a wave of support, with one viewer writing: Don’t look so sad, she lost a great gentleman. Keep moving forward and find the perfect woman who appreciates you.The clip has been viewed over  million times and has made national headlines in Mexico.After going viral, the TikToker addressed the attention, insisting he was over the breakup and that there was no bad blood between him and his ex. He said: Actually I’m fine, I’m fine emotionally, I think so is she. I have nothing against her, we are on good terms. We are not friends, but neither do we hate each other. I only did it to make a TikTok. I didn’t think this was going to get out of control. One viewer urged Uziel not to repeat the mistake, but the TikToker joked that he has no spare kidneys left to donate. We just have two kidneys andI already gave one, I only have another one for me, so … I can’t feel it, he said. Uziel posted his original TikTok in response to a trend in which men recounted their worst experiences with exes. The original trendsetter claimed he had been dumped from Hard University so he could live closer to his girlfriend. But his sacrice amounted to nothing as she too ended up dumping him. title: pod whales spotted freeing humpback
story: Pod of whales spotted freeing humpback they would normally feast on trapped by netsThe “rescue” left onlookers stunned, as orcas are typically known to feast on humpbacks in the ocean - injured or otherwiseSightings of humpback whales swimming in Western Australian waters was unusual for the time of year Image: Whale Watchers Western AustraliaByMirror:,  Jan | commentsA pod of whales have been caught on camera helping to free a humpback whale trapped in a net. The “rescue” left onlookers stunned, as orcas are typically known to feast on humpbacks in the ocean - injured or otherwise. The incredible encounter was captured off the coast of Western Australia, near Bremer Bay on January . According to reports, the humpback whale appeared to be tangled in ropes a position which would typically present it as an easy meal for the feared ocean predators. “It would usually be part of their diet so when we saw the injured humpback and the approaching orca, we were concerned,” Whale Watch Western Australiaaposs Gemma Sharp Sharp told the Mandurah Mail.  Onlookers expected the trio of orcas, named Hookfin, Blade and Matriach Queen, to devour the trapped whale.However, they amazingly appeared to lose interest once the humpback was set free, according toDaily Mail reports . “Lting his fluke we could see that this humpback whale was entangled and our hearts sank,” a statement from Whale Watchers Western Australia read.“ a terrible situation to be in when trying to defend yourself against the ocean apex predators.”  However, while the humpback rolled around in the water, the group watched Blade swimming directly under his fluke and looking at the rope entanglement. The orcas then swam towards the humpback, prompting him to defend himself with pectoral fins and fluke swiping. “Matriarch Queen arrived and moved towards the humpback whale which caused a commotion of white water and then something incredible happened,” Whale Watchers Western Australia said.  “A large chunk of the green rope that was entangling the humpback floated free behind him.” The humpback then swam away from the pod of orcas, having been freed in the nick of time. Witnessing a humpback whale swimming in Western Australian waters in January was also unusual. Humpbacks usually feed in Antarctica at this time of year. news world-news woman-takes-selfie-top-sinking-"Canada: Camera captures moment car drives on frozen river in OntarioByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsA woman found time to capture the moment her car sank into a frozen river with a quick mid-disaster selfie on the roof of the vehicle.The unidentied woman posed for a snap on the roof of her yellow sedan as it slowly descended beneath the surface of the Rideau River in Manotick, a suburb of Ottawa, Canada on Sunday.While she was checking her angles, locals scattered to find a way of rescuing her, eventually grabbing a blue kayak and tying it with rope to drag her out of the massive ice hole. By the time the kayak arrived, only the roof of her car was visible above the sub-zero water. According to witnesses who shared videos of the crash on social media, at one point she said: Oh well. I guess Iaposll walk.  Police responded to the scene at .pm, and charged her with dangerous driving.But driving on ice is not actually illegal in the country, where it snows often, the MailOnline reports. Paramedics also attended but the woman refused treatment, according to Canadaaposs National Post newspaper. One Twitter user recalled seeing the woman drive past him at speed and rip by.He added that he wasnapost surprised she ran into trouble on the ice.  A separate video showed the car careening across the frozen river at a high speed. However, this couldaposve been caused by skidding rather than acceleration. In a press release, the Ottawa Police Service said: @This portion of the river has thin ice compared to other areas of the river. This portion of the river has thin ice compared to other areas of the river,apos said the Ottawa Police Service.  Ice conditions at this time of the year can be unpredictable. The Ottawa Police Service would like to remind residents to stay off the ice and remember aposNo Ice is Safe Iceapos. The vehicle remains where it sank in the river. Police have warned it could be a hazard for people curious while wandering around on the ice. title: dundee mans journey from traumatic offshore accident to shop opening
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Eveningcontent online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Courier. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Tayside and Fe. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Courier and the Eveningnewspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from The Courier and the Evening .Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access The Courier and the EveningePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to The Courier or the EveningePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on    Monday – Friday, am – pm, or email.Your subscription to The Courier will allow you to access all of the Eveningstories which are now available on The Courier website. All of the best Eveningcontent, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on The Courier website and will be available for you as part of your subscription. If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Courier ePaper.The new website is now live. Eveningcontent can now be found on The Courier website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing EveningWeb subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Courier website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Courier website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The Courier website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on   , or email.The new website is now live. Eveningcontent can now be found on The Courier website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. You can access your ePaper on The Courier website.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the EveningePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening  ePaper app will remain exactly the same. If you are an existing EveningWeb subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Courier website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Courier website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Eveninglogin details work on The Courier. To log in please visit www.thecourier login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on   , or email.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Courier website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you need any advice about your current or future subscription options please contact the Digital News Subscription team, on    Monday # Friday, am # pm or via email.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Eveningwebsite is no longer available. If you navigate to the Eveningwebsite or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Courier website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Eveninghere .Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Eveningcontent that you would expect from The Tele website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Eveningcolumnists. These can all be found on The Courier website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from the courts. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Eveningwebsite. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Eveningwebsite.Some Eveningcontent will be moved to The Courier website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Courier website.Yes, The Courier and the Eveningsocial pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The Courier website.Your registration details that you set up on the Eveningwebsite will work on The Courier website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. You now have access to  free articles on the new site. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Eveningbranded newsletters. You will now receive Courier newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Courier has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Courier and the Evening . You can purchase a Courier Web or Courier ePaper subscription here: www.thecourier subscribeThe EveningePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Courier. The Courier Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The Courier and the Evening . You can purchase a Courier Web or Courier ePaper subscription here .If you have an existing EveningWeb subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Courier site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Tele content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an EveningePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. You can purchase both The Courier and the EveningePaper subscription’s here.

story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: governments unite to deliver uk wide fishing policy
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. title: george eustice joint fisheries statement recognises importance of the industry
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: aberdeen detached home walled gardens 460k
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles.
